Fachspezifischer Trainingskurs für kaufmännische Auszubildende in Großbritannien
European College of Business and Management

Due to the increasing globalisation and internationalisation of the working environment it has become more and more important in recent years to prepare the trainees for these challenges in their various jobs. Confident communication with foreign partners requires good knowledge in the world language English on the one hand and on the other hand also a high degree of intercultural competence. Our projects contribute to support our trainees especially in the above mentioned aspects which also corresponds to our school internal quality management understanding (“Schulinternes Qualitätsverständnis – SQV”). After having offered a language course for industrial clerk, bank clerk and office administration clerk trainees at the European College of Business and Management (ECBM) in London for the past years we have now taken the decision to offer a practical training for retail clerk and wholesale clerk trainees with B.I.G. Bristol. “Project 1” mentioned in this application form is the course at the ECBM, “Project 2” is the practical training with B.I.G. Bristol.

After getting in contact with the European College of Business and Management by the recommendation of another vocational school, various teachers of our school took part in a further education course at the ECBM. The experiences we gained there concretised the planning of an own project which was implemented the year after. Both the economic and pedagogic skills of the teachers at the ECBM concerning the transmission of central aspects of the British economy, culture and politics have convinced us to continue this project for more than ten years now.

The decision of offering another project (project 2) has prompted us to choose B.I.G. Bristol as a further partner organisation for retail clerk respectively wholesale clerk trainees. We got familiar with this company during a further education course about “Leonardo DaVinci”. B.I.G. Bristol organise practical trainings which meet the job requirements of our retail clerk and wholesale clerk trainees.

The main aim of project 1 is to enable 24 students from the vocational school "Staatliche Berufsschule II Memmingen" to attend a three-weeks course at the European College of Business and Management in London. The students, who train to be a bank clerk, industrial clerk or office clerk, are all in their second year of vocational training. During the course the students are able to improve their language skills in English as well as their knowledge in business administration issues.

At the college the students attend lessons every working day between 9.30 am and 4.45 pm. The lessons deal with topics which are related to their vocational training in Germany. The lessons are held by specially trained and experienced teachers from the college. In addition to the daily lessons, the participants have to write out an assignment on a special economic or social-economic topic, which is chosen by them individually. This as well as the final presentation at the end of the course, enhances the language skills immensely.

Concerning project 2, 20 wholesale and retail clerk trainees take part in a two-week internship in various commercial companies. They will get a close insight into the job-related practical experience and get the chance to interchange with their British colleagues. 

Next to the course, the students of both projects are obliged to plan and prepare several group excursions. The group leaders decide on relevant topics and talk them over with the students during the preparation meetings. The topics are then prepared in English by the student teams, so that they can be presented by them in London respectively Bristol and the surrounding area during the group excursions. 

Another major aim of the project is to enlarge the intercultural, social and individual skills of the students. They enter a new field with unknown cultural and social requirements, they learn to communicate and to cooperate with students and teachers. Both the projects in London and Bristol focus on the strategy of internationalisation and especially concentrate on an increase of mobility of the students, teachers and employers as well as the internationalisation of the “Berufsschule II Memmingen”.

In 2017 and 2018, 34 participants of the biennial and triennial (see 1) vocational course of State-Certified Commercial Assistants for Foreign Languages, 5 participants of the so called ‘dual educational courses’ (see 2) of Personnel Service Providers, Insurers, Retailers, and 8 participants of the course of Foreign Language Correspondence Clerks/A-levels will take part in the internship programme.
The Commercial Assistants who do their internship at the beginning of their last year of vocational studies then will have substantial demand of both, foreign languages in the field of commercial correspondence and terminology in foreign trade. They will have already obtained knowledge concerning such matters of commercial correspondence as enquiry, offer, order, delay in payment and notice of defects. Further, they will have learned how to handle different types of forms in the field of foreign trade and will have acquired detailed knowledge in the subjects of business administration, national economy and infonomics. In the latter they will have learned how to use computer programmes like Excel, Word and Powerpoint and will be well trained in word processing.
Due to all these skills acquired, they are qualified for working in international importing and exporting enterprises, shipping companies, international industrial concerns and organisations as well as in hotels and/or language schools.
At a time when their state of knowledge enables the trainees to deal with responsible tasks in a company or an institution, the internships offer the opportunity to link their theoretical knowledge with practical training. What concerns us primarily is that for teaching purposes didactically reduced case studies become verified in a real environment in order to enhance the students’ chances on the European labour market.
As this is a full-time vocational school training, the trainees have got few opportunities to work in side jobs to earn their own living. Thus, doing an internship in a foreign country does not only mean financial losses during the time of their stay but also considerable problems in raising the funds for a period abroad. Only if our trainees will be sponsored by the ERASMUS+ programme, we are able to realise our project which is continually carried out and supervised by qualified teachers experienced in this area.
Moreover, this programme constitutes the frame of security, trustworthiness, approval and professional advice and support which is so important to our partners and beneficiaries.
This year’s project of 8 to 11 weeks will be carried out in companies and institutions based in the UK, France, Spain, Ireland, Cyprus, Malta and Turkey. An internship of eleven weeks including the corresponding exam held and certified by a German-French board of examiners will be offered by the grammar schools Lycée St. Etienne and Lycée René-Cassin in Strasbourg.
With that the students are given the opportunity to get their practical skills certified and, thus, to obtain a more favourable starting position on the labour market. For already three years now, we have been applying the ECVET instruments in co-operation with these partners. In recurrently held workshops we regularly update and adjust the instruments to the corresponding needs.
All details described above are mainly applicable to the Foreign Language Correspondence Clerks/A-levels, except the fact that these students are at the initial stage of their vocational training at the time of their internship. The trainees of the dual educational courses benefit from their three-week internship by testing their practical knowledge in other European countries. The teachers draw upon this experience by improving the quality of their training and to provide the entire staff with the newly gained knowledge and competences. 
The participants of the project will benefit considerably and sustainably, both, in their professional and private life from the improvement of their language skills, newly gained cultural insights and, last but not least, their personality development. 

1 The students of the triennial course do a combined degree course of AVCE and State-certified Commercial Assistant for Foreign Languages.
2 Dual courses are a combination of theoretical vocational training at school and practical training in a company.
Doing Business in an Englishspeaking Environment
European College of Business and Management

Context / Background
In the background of economic globalization, it is important, in addition to academically trained to grant also people in vocational training foreign experiences to meet the needs of the world of work and the labor market. An - albeit short – stay abroad within the framework of vocational training shows the mobility of participants, their outstanding commitment and their raising employability.
Objectives
Goals, in addition to improving foreign language skills and professional competence, are mainly promoting self-confidence and initiative as well as the development of tolerance to other cultures and peoples. The described objectives meet the needs of ECVET and will be documented with the europassMobility and europassLanguage. A not unimportant side effect is that with the “Kaufmann International Certificate (AHK)” another formal certificate, an in Germany acknowledged document, will be reached.

Participants Group
The participants are all in initial vocational training in the dual system, or have completed the dual VET recently successful. The participants are recruited primarily from the professions bank clerks and industrial management assistants. Besides, also achievement-weaker find consideration.

Activities
In addition to schooling and language support, find self-regulated learning, working on economic issues with presenting the results as well as excursions to be held in London’s City based companies. The participants are nominated by training companies, which enjoy an excellent reputation for practical vocational training, but who see a clear need to improve the language skills of their trainees and future employees. In addition, a cultural program is offered with mandatory and optional elements.

The flows are planned for the following dates:
1. Flow: 29. April - 19. May 2018
2. Flow: 12. May - 8. June 2019

Intended results and impact
Measurable results in terms of the development of language competence should be able to be derived by the repeated self-evaluation by the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages (CEFR). With the increasing knowledge of the language and foreign experience itself the participants will be prepared to move well in an unknown environment which increases employability as well as their future chances on the labor market. The sending training companies can be sure to find an attractive and up-to-date programme in order to attract more potential job trainees. The awareness of Europe will also be strengthened as well.
Welcome! Fáilte! ¡Bienvenidos! Betriebspraktika und Lernaufenthalte in Großbritannien, Irland und Spanien
European College of Business and Management

In a united Europe aspects such as experiences across the continent and the knowledge of foreign languages become more and more important and evident. The Louis-Baare-Berufskolleg is a vocational college where students complete their training or obtain other educational qualifications. As a so-called "Europaschule" we account for this development.

While doing their work placements and studies as part of the project the selected students gain the above mentioned competences.  These competences cover the needs of the German economy on a global market. The selected participants provide their linguistic and technical skills to the internship company. The successful achievement of everyday work in a company as well as the process of gaining knowledge abroad strenghtens their self confidence. Moreover they learn more about different working methods and mentalities. Through this the students enhance their career prospects within the European Union. Furthermore making positive experiences beyond national borders and also making new friends in other countries reduces prejudices, stereotypes and fears.

Overall 28 students will participate in the programme. Before their stay abroad all students will be prepared for their placements and studies. This includes practical support concerning the organization locally (the booking of flights, accommodation etc.). They will either be accompanied by a teacher or supported via e-mail or telephone. In addition it is planned to visit as many of them as possible.
European College of Business and Management

From the applied contingent of places are 249 for students all over Germany (Pool project). All given standards of the the PP are implemented within our project.
Project background:
During the last few years we have been able to offer the project throughout the entire country and to raise the number of flows (phase from 1.6.2015 - 31.5.2017 so far about 200). At the same time, we have been able to involve more training companies and vocational schools (industrial and business).
Project goals:
Our project aims specifically at enhancing applicants’ job chances through their acquisition of a further qualification. With this main goal, we are confident that participants – in addition to strengthening their self-competence - will improve their communication skills in a foreign language and will absorb new learning methods (informal and non-formal learning) thus strengthening and broadening their overall professional and political competencies. The intention of our project is to enable applicants to participate in the Erasmus+ Programme who otherwise have no such opportunity through a school or an company
Number and profiles of participants:
We have applied for 289 flows for the coming application period, the majority of which for a period of four or more weeks. Most of the participants are in a dual vocational system. Twenty of these applicants are completing their vocational education (horticulture, agriculture and home economics) in a facility for the handicapped and have special needs.
Description of project activities:
The project coordinator carries the main responsibility for preparation, operative implementation and evaluation. Specialised institutions and experts are involved when preparatory seminars are carried out. Language courses are in some instances organized by the participants themselves or – where eligible for funding – are carried out in the respective training companies or schools. These make a preselection of the applicants based on qualitative criteria. We make the final decision on the choice of the participating students.  Our policy is to leave organising accommodation in the target country and making travel arrangements to the participants themselves. We merely assume an advisory and supportive role. Schools and the training companies are involved in the wrap-up.
Procedures for project realisation:
All of the participants are required to submit applications to us (motivation essay, CV etc.) and to take part in our preparatory seminars (general information about the project, EU management game). All applicants receive our brochure with detailed information about the programme. As needed, we assist in the search for partner companies. The preparatory seminars take place at various locations, depending of the participants. Those travelling alone are given individual support. During their stay, participants must prepare a weekly report which has to be sent to the project coordinator the following week by e-mail. There is a total of three evaluation questionnaires that must be completed.
Description of the targeted results and impact
The main goal of our programme is to enhance applicants’ job chances through a further training qualification, which also empowers them to be tolerant and open when dealing with people from other countries as well as to be able to live and work in other countries. We are confident that these main goals will be reflected in broadened political competence in addition to the professional competencies gained. We support workers’ councils in their task of improving the quality of vocational training and to disseminate Erasmus+.
Description of the anticipated long-term benefits 
For training companies, sending trainees on internships is an integral part of personnel development. Through the stays in a foreign country, participants gain an important broadening of their competencies which greatly enhances their employment chances. (The majority of the flows are for four weeks or longer.)  Participants with special needs gain increased independence. Through these transfer activities/mobility measures, our organisation is able to deepen and broaden its competencies and is in a position to implement other European programmes also involved with the first steps in vocational training. The publicity-effective functions at which, together with the Information Centre Europe Direct, we award Europass Mobility, contribute to better public awareness of the European unification.
Come together in Europe; technical and cultural exchange as part of vocational education V

In our project are trainees of several programmes included. There are trainees, who are educated full time in school, we call them "Assistenten", the name of this kind of education programme is Höhere Berufsfachschule (HBFS), within this programme we have four emphases, these are Chemical technology (Chemical technicians), Biological technology (Biological technicians), Media design and information technology.
Additionally to the full time in school educated trainees we include trainees (mostly Biological Lab Assistants) out of the so called dual system.
The main topic of the project "Come together in Europe; technical and cultural exchange as part of vocational training V" is to provide opportunities to our trainees, who come almost out of the rural surroundings of our school, to make vocational experiences abroad in Europe.
We think that the young generation of the current trainees at the time of globalisation won't be able to stay for their whole professional life at home near their place of birth or their place of youth. They will have to be ready to join companies abroad, if they want to be successful in their jobs. In Sweden, as well as in the other countries where we are looking for options for internships, the trainees will meet foreign working cultures, which will not be common to them. They will learn to be a stranger the hard way, during their four week placements. We think this will help to develop broad-mindedness and acceptance for foreign people and cultures within their companies and living environment at home in the rural area of Marburg. Hopefully they will educate their fellow pupils in this way, when they are back from the four week internships.
The coaching of the students abroad will force us teachers as well. Our foreign language competences, especially our skills in using the technical language will increase by the communication with the instructors in the companies abroad. This will have positive effects not only to us but also to the pupils, who were not brave enough so far to do an internship abroad.
European College of Business and Management

Project background:
English is part of the curriculum for business management assistants  at vocational schools with one lesson per week. More and more trainees see themselves confronted with communication in English. Due to rising internationalization and globalization we see the need to qualify our students for these challenges. This is most efficient in an authentic surrounding where you can experiece and acquire new skills in a direct way. Above all, trainees who have not had the opportunity of being supported, i.e. especially not through European exchange programmes, should be enabled to profit from this project.

Learning outcomes:
The participants are expected to deepen both their general and business knowledge of English during the 3-week-course at the European College of Business and Management (ECBM) in London. With the project-related work they shall be encouraged to work on their own, improve their presentation skills as well as develop team-spirit qualifications which are essential in a modern business world. 
Moreover, we want the participants to improve their language competence and gain valuable intercultural experience, build up a healthy self-confidence and develop self-worthiness not only for their professional career. Closely connected we see the project as a door-opener to a positive attitude towards life-long learning and minimizing internal barriers when it comes to work abroad.

Participants: Amount and Profile:
The 20 participants are training to become business management assistants in industry concentrating on the commercial side of the business. They have served at least about half of their traineeship of two and a half respectively three years already. They have gained basic practical experience, a solid knowledge of English, which mainly results from a secondary education, partly higher secondary or A-levels. Their language skills are above average. Basic task-related vocabulary has been acquired at vocational school. There is also a basic knowledge of intercultural communication - partly achieved at vocational school. 

Activities / Implementation:
The course at the ECBM includes lessons as well as group work on projects (assisted by tutors). The students' tasks also include research activities (field, internet, and  other) and a presentation on a chosen subject which is part of the examination. A written executive summary has to follow the presentation. The cultural aspects include an overview on British and London politics, economy and society in lessons as well as excursions with the ECBM. 
At a personal level the participants will be enabled to experience another culture, life in another household and host family, a completely new surrounding in a world city thus learning to understand, respect and accept other people. 
Their language skills will profit immensely not only from the stay at the college but the contact to and within host families as well as managing daily life. The teachers from vocational school accompanying and monitoring the project will take them on cultural tours, e.g. tours of the city, visit museums, concerts, theatre plays, typical markets or sports events, and a trip to Brighton as an example of British seaside resorts.

Results / Long-term outcomes:
On the long run this project will help improve  the participants to develop skills which will enhance performance at the workplace as well as be of personal benefit for the students.  They shall be encouraged to see work abroad as part of their business life and accept life-long learning as an essential part of a professional career. The project may as well serve as a signal to other students. Implementing our corporate philosophy we see this project as a contribution to an international, modern,  and progressive educational and business region.
Our business is our future - Enhancing Students’ and Teachers' International Capabilities
European College of Business and Management

Project background and goals
As the meaning of international qualifications on the job market is increasing and as we have more and more students who are asylum seekers at our school we feel the need to qualify our students and staff for an international job environment. Therefore, we want to improve their language, intercultural, personal and professional competences in order to prepare them for the international job market and to contribute to a tolerant and peaceful environment. In the quality agreement of our school we state that our students and teachers should have the chance to spend some time abroad and to acquire international certificates. 
For the long-term realisation of our projects it’s essential to qualify our teachers step by step. We want to enable them to organize and develop European mobility programmes and partnerships and to teach our students language and intercultural skills in a modern way. 

Project description
One step towards this goal is our mobility project “„Our business is our future – Enhancing Students’ and Teachers' International Capabilities“  that we organize in cooperation with the European College of Business and Management (ECBM) in London. Within the next two years  we want to send 40 students  to the United Kingdom. The students do an apprenticeship as a management assistant in retail business, in wholesale and foreign trade or office management assistants. In order to increase their business knowledge, intercultural experience and language skills the students attend an Intensive Course (PDP - Professional Development Programmes) that takes 3 weeks. In the courses they get an overview of British business and culture and an introduction to their specific areas of occupation and interest which can be built upon at a later stage. There are also excursions that have close relevance to the course topics, e.g. to London Stock Exchange, MINI plant in Oxford, Bosch in Denham, The Bank of England Museum or The Thames Barrier. During their stay at British guest families and in London they gain insights in British life and culture and  improve their cross-cultural competence and understanding.

Second, we sent 6 teachers to the ECBM for one week in order to do a job-shadowing, to improve their language and professional skills and to gather information. They will talk to project managers and to students and will make sure that the quality of our project is maintained and optimized. They also monitor and accompany our students in London and are responsible for the organization of excursions and trips. 

Project success and certificates
The success and quality of the project will be monitored and assessed with different instruments. We rely on instruments like the participants and learning agreement according to ECVET-standards to make the project goals measurable and visible. During their stay the students are monitored by our staff and with a set of feedback instruments we make sure that all of our participants meet the project goals. At the end of their stay our students write a test, do an oral presentation and hand in an executive summary. After the course the students get the European College of Business and Management Attendance Certificate and the German-British Chamber Certificate (AHK London). Moreover, after successful completion of their final exams of the Chamber of Industry and Commerce (IHK) in Germany they can acquire the Kaufmann/-frau International Certificate (KIC), which is officially accredited by the German-British Chamber of Industry & Commerce (AHK) in London.  Moreover, to  validate the competences acquired by the participants during their experiences abroad all participants get the Europass Mobility Document. 
Our teachers also get an attendance certificate of the ECBM  and the Europass. 

Effect
We hope to increase the self-confidence and openness of our participants so that they recognize the meaning of international mobility and to develop their competences. We want to increase their willingness to work with people from other countries and with different cultural backgrounds. We want to contribute to the level of awareness of Erasmus+ projects and share our project results with different stakeholders, like other schools and companies in order to motivate them to take part in an Erasmus activity themselves.
European College of Business and Management

Project aims: 
The participants will get to know the education system and education methods of the partner country. The main challenges of the vocational training will be one of the central aspects which has to be discussed with the partners. They will work on possibilities and the need of international cooperation to solve the challenges. 
Project grounds:
In particular in KUM and VET schools have in practice many difficulties in defining and formulating learning results oriented on competences/skills. Therefore, there is a high training need in particular for the implementation of the ECVET instruments. 
Teachers and trainers play are important role as multipliers. The training of the trainers is sine qua non for innovations in the field of VET.
Description of the activities: The project co-ordinator is responsible in particular for the preparation and Evaluation. We and the involved members of the Konsortium meet a preselection of the participants according to qualitative criteria. Finally we decide who will take part. We are also responsible for organisation, learning outcome and preparation of the stays in arrangement with all partners. The Evaluation and dissemination of the results are to be carried out by all partners. 
Description of the aimed results and effects: The main aims of our project are the improvement of the vocational training, a stronger cooperation of the national partners in VET as well as the cooperation of the education facilities at EU level. We expect that the participants also extend her Euro political orientation beside her technical competence and introduce this into their instructor's and teaching activities. 
Description of the expected long-term use: To train the educational staff is an essential bridge for the opening of the vocational training for necessary innovations and adaptations. Besides, the VET must also provide competence which goes out the purely technical and refers to topical and future challenges: among other things immigration, Inclusion, BNE and digitalisation.
European College of Business and Management

"Mobility as a Challenge - going new ways" is a comprehensive project supporting the mobility of  learners and teachers at Walter Eucken Berufskolleg in Duesseldorf. In the next two years 42 apprentices and 28 teachers will profit from the funding. By putting a growing emphasis on teachers the WEBK is expanding its efforts in implementing the European dimension into the school's profile. Our aim is to embed our European key objectives into all our stakeholders' minds and hearts.

The project provides for different measures.
On the one hand apprentices will have the possibility to gain work experience in different European enterprises and countries, which they will organize themselves. By doing so the apprentices will explore the European labour market, will strengthen their language competence and most important of all will increase their sense of initiative / autonomy as well as their self-confidence,  all of which are decisive factors for increasing their future career chances.


On the other hand teachers will do job shadowing in Austrian and Dutch companies and schools in order to expand both their specialist knowledge and their pedagogical expertise. They will have the opportunity to exchange new ideas and concepts with colleagues from other European countries. Their increased motivation will serve as a multiplier for the whole school raising overall participation in European projects.

As a result of the careful selection of companies and educational institutions abroad teachers can improve the quality of their lessons, thereby offering our students up to date and practically oriented lessons. Furthermore, the participation and development of pan-European networks leads to an increase in knowledge on all sides, especially when transnational content is involved, e.g. logistics.

As another measure to enable more of our staff to participate in and instigate international projects the school will offer teachers to improve their language competence in English and Dutch by attending language courses.

The results of the teacher mobilities will be used to adapt and modernize learning and teaching activities, which will then be made available to all stakeholders, thereby strengthening the co-operation with our partner institutions in a sustainable way.
Migliorare le competenze professionali nel turismo

The Impro.Tour.S  Project is submitted by IAL Toscana Vocational Training Organization, coordinator of the Project Consortium that brings together 4 VET Secondary School in the area of Massa Carrara, Lucca and Pisa in the Tourism and Catering sector with the main aim to answer the need for Training and facilitating young people and student in entering the labour market in these 3 Provinces,  which are identified like “industrial district in crisis” of the Tuscany Region North coast area. In the Economic Report of Tuscan Region 2014 the tourism and catering sector on the tuscan area, particularly in the 3 provinces mentioned above, shows a decline in tourism demand in the recent years.
The needs analysis made by IRPET the Regional Institute for statistic research and study has been confirmed by the companies, from which We have received letters of support and commitment (see attached) to hire people who have had workexperiences with this project. 
General objectives of Impro.Tour.S  are: improving skills in the tourism sector as requested by the job market always changing; developing a stronger language skills in answer to companies needs to have staff with fluent languages; structuring a system to recognizing credits acquired by mobility and transferring them through education/ vocational training /labour market systems in transparency; developing international partnerships able to manage these particular young target groups; writing an handbook for validating mobility activities and recognizing credits from the beginning to the end of the work experiences, putting together in a whole system different certification’s tools coming from different worlds of education and vocational training..
The Project Consortium has selected 6 international partners, with whom has collaborated in the past, and which have strong connections with enterprises in the Tourism and catering sector and big experience in hosting students and young people groups. The Consortium has choosen countries and city centers with a strong calling to tourism so that participants could have a real and effective workexperience. 
With these host partners the mobility management is regulated on the base of a MoU which sets the framework for credit transfer and where there are defined the LO to be assessed, validate and recognized. Besides, the Project Consortium will make a LA which will define which  knowledge and skills should be acquired and finally evaluated. 
Impro.Tour.S  Project will realize 2 mobility paths directed to 2 different target groups, with different ages and L.O.: gr.1 (age16/19) are school’s students, both in the tourism and catering sector, will have a workexperience abroad for 4 weeks; Gr.2 new graduates and newqualificated in tourism and catering sector young people, age 18/20, (realize the workexperience abroad within 1 year from the releasing of the diploma), for this target group the period abroad will be 12 weeks, this has been estimated an appropriated time for developing technical and soft skills, needed to enter the labour market. 
The Consortium has considered that having a mobility experience in sme’s for young students and new graduates is an opportunity to check their skills in the partners’ countries tourism and catering sector: in UK, Spain, Germany, Ireland, Czech Republic and France. The choice of a placement in sme’s and not in big multinational is a specific decision, to give participants a very similar experience to the one They could have in North Tuscany Coast companies and having the idea of which kind of job opportunity They will find in the small enterprises. 
Starting from the selection and a first step of guidance before the leaving, the project’s activities will be focused on the workexperience abroad, where each company tutor will take care of monitoring participants’ skills learning on the workplace, through an employers’ evaluation form, provided by the Consortium. 
One accompanying person/tutor will leave with the school students and course’s participants groups, who are age 16/18: accompanying person/tutor is foreseen each 10 students. At the end of the mobility experience all groups will have improved their skills: professional,cultural, linguistic and relational abilities, self esteem, personal growing, communication, adaptability, flexibility problem solving skills. Consortium members will developed their knowledge as well. Concerning the managing of a trasnational partnership and the ECVET system of evaluation and recognizing learning outcomes and credits, and They will elaborate and handbook about these themes.The final seminar foreseen will be the occasion which will create long term effects and stimulate a change on the area about labour market active policies and school’s didactic programs.

The project "ARTITUDE", will last 24 months and is addressed to 100 students attending the III and IV grade at the I. I. S.S. "Pantini – Pudente in Vasto (CH), the  I.I.S. "Mattei” located in Vasto (CH), and the national Convitto “G.B.Vico” (Liceo Artistico e Classico) in Chieti.  The project meets the need to further qualify the human resources involved in the mobility. This will be achieved through a 1-month internship in host organisations  for students in the  field of management /enhancement/promotion of artistic and cultural heritage (museums, agencies of cultural promotion, cultural associations).  This is a developing sector in Europe and,  in spite of the crisis, it can offer new and qualified employment opportunities.
In fact, thanks to the work placements -in European cities (London, Plymouth, Cork, Amiens, Valencia and Derry) where artistic and cultural heritage are widely enhanced and where the sector is an important employment source-  it is intended to offer an “on the job" learning opportunity   in foreign companies and institutions , in order to integrate students’ school education by ensuring  improvement of their professional and entrepreneurial skills especially in relation to:  1)technical and professional abilities in the specific fields of cultural offer management, enhancement/promotion of artistic/cultural products/services, 2) abilities to find the way through an increasingly open market and  evaluate the opportunities arising from such growing openness; 3) abilities to meet the demanding requirements from users of cultural services/ products; 4) abilities to innovate, diversify and increase performances  of public and private organisations that manage the cultural offer. In order to have a successful project a partnership has been created. It involves regional and transnational organisations committed to the training and professional development of young human resources and to the quality improvement of cultural supply. In fact the partnership includes:institutions, employer associations, companies and non-profit partners that will work together to promote a quality cooperation and the enhancement of knowledges/skills of young people. In the preparation of the project, the European Quality Charter for mobility has been taken into account for the following issues: selection procedure, learning plans, individualisation, linguistic aspects, logistic support, certification of learning  outcomes.
It is foreseen that beneficiary students, on their return from the mobility, together with the national partners participating in the Consortium, prepare a Plan for management and improvement of one or more cultural/artistic  goods in the Abruzzo Region to be promoted at European level.  Beneficiaries will be concretely involved in the enhancement of a specific artistic/cultural proposal in order to harness the new gained competences so that companies  in the reference sector could consider proposals from the human resources of the schools  involved in the mobility. Thanks to ARTITUDE project, the Consortium aims also to lay the foundations for long term collaboration with the local and transnational partnership and to consolidate, in the long run, the connection between schools and business at European level.
Opening doors to VET students employment in Europe

The project responds to the need that VET schools have to provide their students with the chance to increase and improve the quality of vocational training, by taking internships in European companies, and getting in contact with the single European labour market.

This project stems from the successful cooperation of the previous partnership promoted by the IES Simarro, from the high rate of students’ employment that has been achieved (80%), from the interest and high level of satisfaction that have been expressed by both students and coordinating teachers that participated in the previous project as well as from the smooth and close cooperation, developed by partnership’s VET schools. It has propitiated the present project that will.meet the demands of educational VET Schools, enhancing better relationships among them  and national and European companies.

The project is addressed to 72 VET students and former students: second-year students of middle level vocational training of Tourism and Gastronomy, Computer Science and Administration or recent graduated (who graduated the last year), like mid-level technician of the mentioned professional sectors. 
The project foresees 8 mobility flows: 4 to Italy, 1 to France, 1 to Poland and 2 to United Kingdom. 

Each VET school will select 3 former students and 9 students. The project foresees that 4 mobility flows will be carried out to Italy as the profile of the Italian partners as well as the different geographical areas they are located, will provide the students with the chance to be trained in very diverse companies of the same sectors.

The main objective of the ODEE project is to promote student’s development of skills and competences through internships in companies in order to integrate the vocational competences they have already acquired and to efficiently enter the single European labour market. Therefore, students need, from one hand, to develop specific and technical skills in their professional sector, and from another hand, they also need to acquire and improve other key competencies, like cultural, linguistic, entrepreneurship, personal initiative, team, as well as to acquire knowledge about new different work environments. All these competences will enhance student’s access to the EU labour market, both as self-employee and/or hired worker.

The main ACTIVITIES that partners of the project will carry out are:
- PREPARATION of the motilities: selection of the participants, initial evaluation of their competences, pre-departure training of participants, logistics and agreements’ tasks definition, coordination, etc.
- IMPLEMENTATION OF THE MOBILITY. Implementing the internship programs in the companies. The mobility also includes cultural activities.
- EVALUATION OF THE PARTICIPANTS. The competences that will be acquired during the stay abroad will be evaluated according to the ECVET system and will be previously set, during the initial evaluation. All the internship activities will be planned to achieve these competences and will be customized.
- MONITORING. The development of the internships will be monitored by all the tools and processes, previously agreed by the project.
- EVALUATION OF THE PROJECT. 
- DISSEMINATION. The dissemination activities will be carried out in all project’s phases. A final conference for the dissemination of the project’s results will be organized. Besides the impact on the participants, the project will benefit all partners, fostering the European cooperation and relationships between companies and educational centres.

The DISSEMINATION activities and the mobility itself will generate an IMPACT at local, regional and national level. 
The impact on the partnership’s VET schools will be:
- Improving qualifications and competitiveness of youngsters, enabling them to adapt to the digital era’s demands and to a global knowledge-based economy, enhancing , at the same time, the increase of the youth employment and a sustainable growth.
- Consolidating and increasing contacts with European entities to modernise education, to share good practices and to develop new projects in the field of European cooperation
- Improving the quality of the training, delivered in the school, and adapted to linguistic, social and cultural diversity. This will allow schools to meet disadvantaged people’s needs in a more efficient way and to understand better what active European citizenship is.
- Improving knowledge and the use of evaluation and certification tools (ECVET and EUROPASS). 
- Increasing the attractiveness of vocational training education, to make it the first selected option for students and enhancing the prestige of the participating VET schools.

The project is strictly related to the 2020 Strategy and the New Skills Agenda for Europe 2016; it is consistent with the strategic priorities for contributing the increase in employment, productivity and social cohesion in the EU and its member states.
Work based learning in Europe for more and better jobs and a fair and open society

Considering the labour market’s functional changes and its modernization, as well as the very high youth unemployment rate (more tan 50%) and the dropout rate among VET students without any professional qualification, educational systems are clearly facing the challenge of improving student’s professional improvement, incrementing their participation as active citizens in the society, and their employability inside and outside the European labour market.
The project aims at providing VET students with the chance to deepen and improve the quality of their training, by carrying out internships in European companies, and getting in contact with European labour market. 
The close cooperation among the VET Schools that are members of the consortium, set the basis for the development of this project.
The consortium is composed by 9 VET schools of the Valencian Region, coordinated by the IES Ramón Esteve.
The consortium VET schools need to establish European quality networks with companies and other educational centres throughout Europe, in order to stay update on innovations, to share good practices and to get informed on European policies, improving the quality of the provided teaching and trainings, thus fighting youth unemployment. 
The project is addressed to former students and students who are attending the 2nd course of school-based intermediate VET programme in Computer Science and Communication, and Administration, or to former students just graduated, i.e. technicians in the above mentioned professional sectors. 
The project foresees the participation of 72 VET students, distributed in 8 flow: 4 to Italy, 1 to Portugal, 1 to Latvia and 2 to United Kingdom. Each centre will select 2 former students (technicians) and 6 students.
It is worth mentioning that relations with the European partners fostered reciprocity, as all the participating transnational centres has also submitted a mobility project in which Spanish consortium will receive their students. The reciprocity will enhance the promotion of the European active citizenship.
The 1 year project will last from the 1st of July 2017 to the 30th of June 2018. The internship will be carried out from the 15th of March to the  30th of May 2018.  
The following activities will be structured in 5 phases:
E1- Activities for communicating and spreading information to promote the students’ participation, planning tasks (including participants’ selection), establishing Learning Agreements, reviewing of ECVET documents, logistics and organization (insurance, lights and accommodation), determining contract-related issues, selecting hosting companies, tutors and accompanying teachers, setting up a common dissemination plan.
E2-Preparation of the mobilities. Information Meeting, signing contracts, linguistic, cultural and professional preparation, OLS registration for students.
E3- Implementation of mobilities. Follow-up, evaluation and certification of participants. Competences will be determined in the Learning Agreement and will be evaluated, using the ECVET instruments and will be certifies by Europass. 
E4- Quantitative and qualitative evaluation of the overall project’s results.
E5- Dissemination. The dissemination activities will be carried out throughout the project’s duration. An extraordinary staff meeting will be held in all the consortium centres. A Final Conference will be also organized.
In addition to the impact on the participants, the project will also benefit all the partners, by fostering  European cooperation and the relationships between companies and educational centres. 
Both dissemination activities and the mobility experience itself will produce an impact at local, regional and national level. 
Other local, regional and national entities will be able to to benefit from the project’s results (even though they are not partners of the project):
- Creation of a quality network that include educational centres and companies
- Decrease in youth unemployment rate
- Improvement of youth qualifications
- Increase in VET enrolment 
- Creation of new collaborative networks at regional level
- Widening the possibility of internationalization for other centres, and their chance to be part to other European projects
- Better knowledge of the Erasmus+ programme and EU values (tolerance, equity, equality and inclusion).
- Fostering the sense of European active citizenship and respect of other cultures
- Possibility to create new companies and new business models 
- Promotion of social inclusion
The project is in accordance with the Strategy 2020, the New Skills Agenda for Europe 2016 and the Erasmus+ objectives, improving the professional development of the students, their participation as active citizens in society and and their employability inside and outside the European Labour market

More than 35% of students regret within one year their job or choice of studies. Students often don't know what they want or don't know their options. They go through an unclear orientation phase and decide at the last moment. Drop-out rates are extremely high.  Students in vocational training are confronted with a professional choice that doesn't suit them at all.
All these students need better guidance regarding  their possibilities. As a school we have the responsibility to support them during this process. students should be able to testdrive the sector of their choice during an internship in different working situations. This helps students to asses the different aspects from their future professional life.
During internships new compettences will be developed. Students experience companyculture and learn to cope with the demands of employers. They learn to engage actively in their own future.
The feedback from both participants and workplacements are invaluable for the school itself to evaluate their own programs, but also for the function it has as a job-orientation counselor. Accompanying persons can spot new trends, technologies ad practices and bring these new ideas back to the school.
On a yearly base students of the program 'managing and undertaking' get the opportunity at a 2 week internship in companies in Londen. Students of industrial cooking of the fifth year undergo  a cooking internship in Greece. Students of the sixth year get the opportunity to go to the far North, Norway.

The seminar organized by Amaro Foro e.V. will bring together 40 Roma and non-Roma multipliers and youth activists from 11 European countries (Germany, Macedonia, Bulgaria, Romania, Hungary, Estonia, United Kingdom, Turkey, Italy, Austria,France, and Spain) aims to develop a comprehensive approach on the issue of Genocide remembrance and education of marginalized youth, their effective involvement and participation in local, national and international programmes, to strengthen cooperation and relations between Roma and non-Roma youth and youth organizations in order to strengthen the conceptual understanding for inter-cultural dialogue, youth inclusion, empowerment and mobilization, as well active citizenship and to establish a support system for enhancing Roma youth capacities and developing new projects within the new Erasmus plus Programme. Moreover, the project will look into practices and methods for youth inclusion and empowerment among youth organizations in addressing and fighting discrimination, racism, xenophobia, especially antigypsyism as a modern form of racism towards Roma and help developing a collective memory of remembrance and commemoration by raising awareness about the 7Holocaust and Roma genocide during WWII. The 8 days seminar "Nothing about us, without us!"will take place on December 1-8, 2017 in Berlin, Germany representing an opportunity for young people that are capable of addressing human rights issues in grassroots, national and international actions. 
The seminar aims to strengthen the coordinated efforts of building joint initiatives on grassroots level, as well as on international level towards the commemoration and to challenge antigypsyism and racism in Europe. This project will not only increase the knowledge and sensitivity of the young Europeans on the topics, but the increased awareness of the young Roma and non-Roma can strengthen the consciousness of the participants about their role and responsibility within their communities, the society and in Europe at large. Strengthening cooperation between young Roma and non-Roma, and different youth and human rights organizations will be another step in building the collective historical memory, awareness and respect for human rights and impulse to a wider official recognition by European countries of August 2nd, as a day of commemoration of the Roma Genocide during World War II. April 15, 2015 marked a historical moment, The European Parliament voted with an overwhelming majority to finally adopt a resolution which recognizes “the historical fact of the genocide of Roma that took place during World War II” and concludes “that a European day should be dedicated to commemorating the victims of the genocide of the Roma during World War II.” Of huge importance is the fact that this resolution also “underlines the need to combat anti-Gypsyism at every level and by every means, and stresses that this phenomenon is an especially persistent, violent, recurrent and common place form of racism.”

Übergang von der beruflichen Ausbildung in die Arbeitswelt
European College of Business and Management

In our two previous projects the participants compared the processes of personnel planning and personnel recruitment in Germany and in our partner countries.

Project A:
In our new project the emphasis will be on the transition from vocational training to employment and its requirements and challenges.

The students will do an internship for 3 to 4 weeks in our partner countries (Poland, Finland and Spain) and have to identify requirements that job starters have to meet, but also obstacles and challenges that both companies and job starters have to face. The students will hopefully gain new qualifications and knowledge, get prepared for the international job market but also reflect and analyse their own competences and skills.

In a second step, the participating teachers will do a job-shadowing week in our partner schools and should get an overview about the skills, competences, professional knowledge and key qualifications that are being taught during the students' vocational training. They will then compare those with the students' findings and deduce recommendations for action and good-practice-examples.

The project assignments will be as follows:
Students' project assignment: identifying typical tasks and activities of job starters, required qualifications, support measures and activities of the company (e.g. mentoring, introductory weeks, seminars) as well as obstacles and challenges. They should compare those results with their own experiences (self-reflexion).

Teachers' project assignment: identifying the skills, competences, business knowledge and key qualifications that are being taught during the students' vocational training as well as the measures to prepare the students for entering the international job market (internationalisation strategy of the school). Desirable would also be results and findings concerning the preparation for the job market of disadvantaged groups (refugees and inclusion). Since our school has started with CLIL (Content and Language Integrated Learning) lessons last September and our Spanish partner school has already been practising CLIL for several years an exchange of experiences concerning that topic is planned as well.

The results of both students and teachers will then be used to answer the following question: "In what way does the vocational training prepare the job starters for the requirements of the professional practice/the job reality?" The results will then be translated into guidelines, recommendations and good-practice-examples.

In the near future a cooperation with an Italian school is planned. Contacts with an Italian school have already been established and will be further intensified.

Project B:
Besides the mobilities of project A the school will also send 20 students per year to the European College for Business and Management in London. The students will take part in a three-week professional development programme (PDP). The business courses will be held in English and focus on international business and finance, but also Business English and international competences. After completing the PDP course the students can apply for the Kaufmann/-frau International Certificate (KIC). It will be awarded by the German-British Chamber of Industry and Commerce (AHK London), which operates under the umbrella of the German Association of Chambers of Industry and Commerce (Deutscher Industrie- und Handelskammertag, DIHK Berlin). Certificate holders prove that they are able to operate in an international business environment.

Both projects will underline and support the internationalisation of our students and will provide them with the professional and personal qualifications, skills and knowledge necessary for being able to compete on the international job market in a further together growing Europe.
European College of Business and Management

The majority of young people in Germany are trained in a scheme which is called „dual system“. During their training they are employed by companies which train them on the job. On one or two days of the week the young people, who are called apprentices, attend a vocational school. They are eligible to be trained in order to get those skills required for a career in the envisioned business or trade. This implies to acquire English language proficiency on the job. Especially industrial companies, logistics firms and companies in the whole sale trade need employees with these skills. Companies and employers need that type of personell functioning effectively in a crosscultural environment. Our vocational school (bsnu) cannot transfer those skills completely as the curriculum only provides 45 minutes per week to train our students in English language and cross-cultural skills. According to academic studies native speakers of English can teach students, who learn English as a foreign language, more efficiently than  indigenous teachers. This course aims at improving our students’ professional competency as well as British culture and doing business in the United Kingdom. The course is designed for 24 participants. We will only take apprentices who attend our school and work in companies which provide business orientated training in professions like industrial clerks, logistics clerks or wholesale clerks. Sometimes we have applicants from the retail trade or students who are trained in managing warehouses. The majority of our students have an intermediate level of education. Only a small number of students have A-levels. Applying for our Erasmus+ project does not require A-levels. We recommend applying for participating in an Erasmus+ project of our school in the first or second year of their training because going to London in their final year may distract some students from preparing well for their final exams carried out by a chamber of commerce and industry. A group of bsnu teachers and Ms Sarah Iles of ECBM designed a concept and procedures for new Erasmus+ projects. We inform our students about new projects by handing out flyers and leaflets. We also put information about the projects on the bsnu website. Our teachers inform their students in the classrooms about our planned projects. We will send letters to companies which have taken apprentices to provide information about the project. When apprentices apply for participating in our project they must provide a written statement of their company showing they agree that their apprentice will be in London for three weeks during their regular period of vocational training. After evaluating the application forms we will choose the participants. If a company indicates their apprentices require English and cross-cultural skills on the job in an extensive manner, those applicants will be put on a priority list. The advices and recommendations of the remaining companies and of teachers from our school, who teach those applicants, will also be considered when choosing participants. In future we will not provide any English language courses for the participants. They have to use online courses provided by Erasmus+ to improve their English proficiency. However, we will go on providing cross-cultural training and a specific training for the ECBM course in London. We will only send one group of twentyfour students to London per year. According to our plans this will be in May/June 2018. Ms Yu Fengyan and Mr Albrecht Hofmann from our school will accompany the group when travelling to London. They will stay with the group in London for three weeks and will join the group on their journey back to Germany. The accompanying persons will monitor the group and their learning achievements. Ms Sarah Iles and the ECBM lecturers will be in charge of the teaching and motivation of the group while they are trained in London. After three weeks in London the participants can show in a presentation and in a written exam what they will have learned. After returning from London to Germany, the participants will have to write an executive summary in English (1000 words) about the topic which they presented as a PowerPoint presentation at ECBM. Our school will collect the participants’ documents and pass them on to ECBM in London. 
Unfortunately a majority of British people voted that Grat Britain should  leave the European Union (brexit). As we focused our international activities on the UK, we assume that in future there will be no EU-funded Erasmus+ projects with the UK as country of destination. We are searching new partners and networks in Ireland and Malta.
Auszubildende und Lehrer aus Bremen Erkunden Europa
European College of Business and Management

Our Internationalisation Concept is focussed on providing language and intercultural training for competent specialists with the option of obtaining further qualifications to enhance their mobility. At the heart of the development process towards achieving these declared aims lie the structuring and execution of additional international mobility projects.

Our three-week Business Communication Competence project in London has a number of core elements – acquiring intercultural competence through pertinent language seminars, the completion and presentation of a team project highlighting professional language fluency. It concludes with a certificate of proficiency graded according to the Common European Framework of Reference and will be offered in this form in future. In addition, it serves as a basis for the planning and execution of projects with an alternative concept: two-week placements in cooperation with tried and new partners with the objective of exchanging views and experience of professional practice through company visits and discussion with all of those involved in vocational training. Furthermore, relevant topics can be included flexibly, e.g. current developments in the EU.

Our contact to Lycée Pierre de Coubertin, Calais, will be reactivated. Rather than the previous three-week twinning with the emphasis on work placement, the future emphasis will be on small groups interacting and discussing. For trainees and teaching staff alike this should enable an international exchange of outlooks – not necessarily in English alone. Sitting in on lessons, company visits as well as extramural activities provide for enhanced intercultural competence and the opportunity for didactic reflection and development.

The relationship with Omnia, in Espoo, Finland, should develop along similar lines, whereby English will be paramount. By bringing together compatible professional sectors, greater emphasis will be placed on topics specifically related to the sector in question.

Our new partnership with LSE in Liverpool provides two further offers meeting our aspirations: for our apprentices language development is the primary objective flanked by company visits with groups formed more on the basis of the level of fluency rather than their training focus. As our English department expands and is strengthened through the Vocational College English Qualification at the Oldenburg Further Education Centre, Liverpool runs a particularly apposite intensive course culminating in the Cambridge Teaching Knowledge Test (TKT). Participants not only consolidate specific vocabulary, but also through teaching their main subject to the Liverpool study group explore, expand and develop didactic approaches. A parallel course offered by the established International Study Programme gives us even greater flexibility to enable our staff to acquire further qualifications.

Hitherto we have offered our apprentices the professional KMK English Language certificate at Level B2. The successful initiation of the Europakaufmann qualification in cooperation with five other internationally engaged Bremen vocational colleges has attracted 47 participants in 2017. Along with concentration on the theme of International Commerce, the English KMK Certificate Level B1, qualification in a further foreign language at minimum Level A1 and the ECDL, a three-week work placement abroad with intercultural interaction is also required. For this we have the partners Liverpool and ECBM with their great experience. The europass will be issued for this.

Sending staff to support participants has definitely enhanced the success and quality of our Mobility projects to date and further strengthened the Internationalisation awareness of accompanying staff. Our expanding concept for Mobility involves intensifying the participation of staff in project activities. They will have the added opportunity for comparing international approaches to vocational training and an exchange on didactics with their opposite numbers in vocational institutions. The ensuing reflection and multiplication of their experiences in various locations will promote the internationalisation of our college.

Based on the contents of the Internationalization Strategic Plan (version 2015) the same aims the strengthening and consolidation of services currently in place and the strengthening of the networks of which Accademia europea di Firenze is already a member.
In particular according with the Plan, it will proceed, for 2017-2019, to:
-manage Europedirect Service under Municipality of Florence, to support educational quality processes of European programs and in particular on international mobility, as a learning tool and qualification
-improved, making system and dissemination of their own management tools and mentoring of international mobility paths, through continuous update of the manual about management of mobility path and born through the T-Tactic @ School project (www.tactic@school.eu)
- consolidation of local networks and international partnership; Stronger and powerful  of vocational courses on the subject of europrojecting, specifically aimed at teachers of secondary school (thanks to the accreditation of the courses at the Ministry of Education) of the region covered by the training and with the right to exemption; upgrading training for counselors and personal shopper; for all paths it provides for the possibility to carry out the training as a part  of international apprenticeship
-implementation and use of the online platform created under the EU project  JOBS IMPULSE (www.gojobgo.eu), funded by the Erasmus + KA2 action program for job seekers and for people who  gained experience of international mobility in order to facilitate the entrance into the job market . Other aims is, also, to make visible and accessible the European instruments for the recognition, validation and the transparency of skills and qualifications
The planned activities within the project S.A.T  allow to implement the actions mentioned above in the following way:
1)International  Internship for  5 students of AEF attending courses on Europrojecting, , counseling and personal shopper. This activity will be held for 10 days (+ 2 travel) in the UK and Spain
The LO identified are:
Counselor: Knowledge of the national legislation and the qualifications system (professional counselor); ability to work in team and create synergies with other personal care services; uses knowledge of counseling techniques and support to educational paths or growth; ability to work in a European language in mother tongue; empathic attitude and respect for diversity.
Europrojecting: understanding of the European framework; knowledge Erasmus + program and its various actions with specific depending on the hosting companies focus; understanding call for proposals; skills in identifying needs and defining objectives of a project; ability to work in teams; ability to work in a European language in mother tongue; ability to process design and synthesis report; autonomy and respect for diversity.
Personal shopper: ability to identify the needs and tastes of the customer; ability to identify, with the customer, the main shopping areas and the target market segments; knowledge of photoshop and adobe; marketing knowledge, strategic communication; ability to work in a European language other than their mother tongue, in a multicultural team, ability to establish empathetic relationships with customers, respect for diversity.
2) International Internship for 5 graduates, 2 of which with attendant basic care qualification and 3 with beautician qualification. This activity will be held for 30 days (+ 2 travel) in Spain and Malta
The LO identified are:
(ADB) to support the user's autonomy, addressing situations of need, implement therapeutic programs, implement simple sanitation interventions;
(Beautician) apply construction techniques, sanitation, operating environments for beauty treatments
3) International Internship for 5 tutors. This activity will be held for 10 days (+ 2 travel) in the UK and Spain.
The LO identified for tutors are: consolidation of basic knowledge in support of the coaching theories; knowledge principles of mentoring; knowledge of tutoring tools in different locations depending on the receiving facilities; ability to establish empathetic relationships; active listening skills, openness attitude; genuine respect for diversity; tolerance of ambiguity. 
The 3 activities include management as stated in VET Charter. Accompany persons are not provide as it's an adult audience and self. The project will be realized in the following flows: 5 people in June 2018, 5 people in February 2019, 5 people in March2019.

These tasks were foreseen for development of internalisation:
1.To iniciate and implement international projects, to encourage interaction between school and companies, to create conditions for teachers and students to adopt technological inovations, foster entrepreneurship, multiculturalism. 
2.To create conditions for teachers and students to participate in exhange programmes and skill competitions.
3.To be a host organisation in Erasmus+ projects, to organise  exhange programmes for incoming teachers and students, to share the best experience.
4.To cooperate with business companies, to participate in projects together. To invite professionals-lecturers from abroad.
5.To intensify cooperation with partners from North and South Europe, United Kingdom.
6.To strenghten mentoring, assurance of the quality in projects.
Plan is to send 40 students and 24  teachers for placements. One incoming teaching visits is planned (from Italy).
Partnerships with Belgium,  Portugal, France are updated, closer cooperation with vocational schools. ECVET elements are negotiated  with the host partners, in order to reach better students‘ achievements recognition.
It is planned to send various specialties students, according to internalisation strategy. Cooks, waiters and bartenders, confectioners, recreational service workers,  sport club activities organizers will go to placements. They  will go to Spain (2 flows 7 students in one flow), 10 students to United Kingdom, 10 cooks to Italy, 6 students to Portugal. It is planned to send leading teachers to all countries.
Teachers will go to a job shadowing visits to Belgium, Spain, United Kingdom and France. Participants will visit vocational schools with similar teaching programmes and basis. Topic of the visits: assurance of vocational training quality. They will observe colleagues‘ work, discuss practical training organisation issues, evaluation and self-evaluation documents, help and mentoring of pupils. Vocational teachers and administration will go to visits, they  learn about educational systems, quality management, plan further students‘ placements. Teachers‘ visits will be recognised as improvement of   qualification, they will be asked to describe the impact and present new experience to colleagues, students.
Host partners will describe students‘ results using ECVET elements. Marks and results will be transfered to a student diary, as part of practical training abroad, it will be recognised, according to agreed topics with vocational teacher, host organisation, and a participant  in advance. Project coordinator, vocational teachers and mentor will cooperate.
ECVET elements will be used: memorandum of understanding will be discussed and signed with host partners. Learning agreements will be signed (sending, host organisations and participants will sign them), description of learning outcomes. It is planned to recognise learning outcomes acquired in non-formal way too. Host partners will issue recomendations for participants, according to their skills.
Project impact: vocational teachers improve their qualification, reflect on teaching content, share expierence, organise skill competitions, events. Administration staff share experience, update and create teaching programmes, improve management, project organisational, foreign language skills. Teachers will get experience how to promote motivation, use personalisation and differentiation.  Participants are  interested in skills and competencies important  for students‘ future career.
School improves status in region, is becoming more open and atractive  to society, social partners, promotes vocational training. 
Impact for students: vocational training according to international standarts, competitiveness of  specialties in Lithuania,  training  orientated to career, opportunities to know other cultures, sociocultural environment, to improve foreign language skills.
Project dissemination  activities. Participants will prepare reports, present gained experience, knowledge to teachers, trainers and community. Teachers  will prepare reports, give open lessons, events. Presentations will be given in methodological groups,  during teachers‘ meetings. Stands about project will be prepared for community. The final meeting will be organized after implementation of the project, representatives of  vocational  schools, social partners will be invited. Information will be shared during  „Open doors“ events at school. Foreign partners will disseminate project activities in their social networks, websites.
